article.title: Naturalizing Gravity of the Quantum Fields, and the Hierarchy Problem

multiple_choice_question.text: What distinguishes the naturalization mechanism in this article from more traditional solutions like supersymmetry or extra dimensions?
choices: It relies on a new, undiscovered force beyond the four known forces.
It posits that the universe has more than four spacetime dimensions.
It incorporates gravity by reinterpreting the UV scale as curvature, eliminating the need for new particles interacting with the Standard Model.
It introduces superpartner particles for every known particle in the Standard Model.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the meaning of "Higgs-phobic" in the context of Beyond the Standard Model physics?
choices: It refers to particles that interact strongly with the Higgs field, leading to instability.
It describes new physics models that rely on modifications to the properties of the Higgs boson.
It denotes models where new particles couple very weakly to the Higgs field, avoiding destabilization.
It indicates particles that are expected to be produced abundantly in Higgs boson decays.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is "Ebony Matter" as proposed in the article?
choices: A form of dark matter that interacts electromagnetically with normal matter.
A type of dark energy that directly affects the expansion of the universe.
A hypothetical form of dark matter that only interacts gravitationally.
A theoretical particle that mediates interactions between dark matter and dark energy.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the article address the cosmological constant problem?
choices: It proposes a new mechanism that cancels the vacuum energy contributions entirely.
It suggests that the cosmological constant is not a fundamental constant but evolves over time.
It resolves the UV divergence of the vacuum energy by reinterpreting those contributions as defining the gravitational constant.
It postulates that the observed acceleration of the universe\'s expansion is not due to a cosmological constant but to a yet unknown force.
